jeopardy_round: WHAT AM I DOING IN NEW JERSEY?

(1, 1).clue: In 1975 George Carlin was the first host of this late night comedy show

(2, 1).clue: This word for a food-storage closet comes from a word meaning "bread room"

(3, 1).clue: James Lind's 1753 "Treatise On" this vitamin C deficiency suggests eating citrus fruits

(4, 1).clue: How 'bout them football teams of Louisiana Tech & the University of Georgia that both sport this nickname

(5, 1).clue: In 1976 N.J. voted to permit gambling casinos here to raise money for the disabled & elderly; the first opened in 1978

(6, 1).clue: A clovis point is a Native American one

(1, 2).clue: One of Carlin's comic character creations was Al Sleet, a hippie-dippie member of this profession

(2, 2).clue: The French name of this piece of furniture indicates it should be used to store weapons, not clothes & TVs

(3, 2).clue: The diseased lymph gland seen here might tip you to the identity of this colorful 2-word killer of the 14th century

(4, 2).clue: Bill Clinton & Antonin Scalia both graduated from this D.C. university founded in 1789

(5, 2).clue: The state capital was named for a merchant & landowner with this 5-letter name

(6, 2).clue: A devoted follower of Jerry Garcia's band

(1, 3).clue: From 1977 until 2008, George starred in 14 specials on this cable TV network

(2, 3).clue: The first chapter of a C.S. Lewis novel is called "Lucy Looks Into" one of these

(3, 3).clue: This lung disease isolated in 1882 has been found in an ancient mummy, so there should be hieroglyphic Christmas seals

(4, 3).clue: Western hats off to you if you know this Florida university was founded in 1883 in the city of DeLand

(5, 3).clue: In 1879 the first practical incandescent lamp was developed in this community

(6, 3).clue: They call themselves Canada's oldest independent brewery, eh

(1, 4).clue: In the 1960s George appeared with Marlo Thomas on this sitcom

(2, 4).clue: In many preschools, kids keep their things in these cozy "holes"

(3, 4).clue: John Enders was awarded a Nobel Prize for his work on this disease that ends with -myelitis

(4, 4).clue: USC has a satellite campus on this island about 25 miles off L.A.'s coast

(5, 4).clue: In 1910 this ex-Princeton Pres. was elected Governor of N.J. but served only 2 years before taking a new job

(6, 4).clue: A monarch in title who has no real authority

(1, 5).clue: In 2008 at the Kennedy Center, George posthumously received the prize for humor named for this man

(2, 5).clue: This 3-letter word can be a coal scuttle or a trough for carrying bricks

(3, 5).clue: This type of inflammatory bowel disease is named for one of the doctors who wrote about it in 1932

(4, 5).clue: The University of Texas at Austin has erected a statue honoring this founder of the United Farm Workers

(5, 5).clue: In 1994 she became the first woman governor of N.J; she'd later be in a president's cabinet & on "Jeopardy!"

(6, 5).clue: Nickname for a U.S. Marine, perhaps from the shape of his haircut

(1, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew shows a constellation on the monitor.)  Look for the Big Dipper to find this third largest constellation: the handle forms its tail; other stars form its paws

(3, 1).clue: In 1581 this world-circumnavigating sailor was made the mayor of Plymouth, England

(4, 1).clue: In his oath one of these pledges that "On my honor I will do my best to do my duty to God & my country"

(5, 1).clue: "If they give you ruled paper, write the other way" is the epigraph to this classic by Ray Bradbury

(6, 1).clue: Ironically, shopping options for women who wear these sizes, French for "small", are shrinking

(1, 2).clue: This hunter constellation is well-armed: he's got a raised club, a shield & a sword dangling from his belt

(3, 2).clue: Tsangyang Gyatso, the sixth man to hold this title, died mysteriously in 1706

(4, 2).clue: The likeness of God used in this 1975 Monty Python comedy is a picture of British cricket star W.G. Grace

(5, 2).clue: "The heart is half a prophet", Philip Roth's epigraph to "Goodbye, Columbus", is a proverb from this language

(6, 2).clue: This egg dish that's often fat & fluffy has a name derived from a middle French word for "knife blade"

(1, 3).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew shows a constellation on the monitor.)  Marking its head, Antares is the brightest star in this constellation; the two stars here represent the sting in its tail

(3, 3).clue: This man who lost the 1948 presidential election was referred to as "the little man on the wedding cake"

(4, 3).clue: A deaf student becomes involved with a speech teacher in this Tony-winning play by Mark Medoff

(5, 3).clue: The epigraph of this Willa Cather novel about life on the Nebraska prairies is "Those fields, colored by various grain!"

(6, 3).clue: This collective term for fowl innards often found in gravy is from an Old French word for a game stew

(1, 4).clue: No bull--the Pleiades are found in this constellation of the zodiac

(3, 4).clue: This U.S. mayor who died in 1976 was called the "last of the big-city bosses"

(4, 4).clue: The song "Day By Day" is from this 1970s musical

(5, 4).clue: The 2-word epigraph to his "Howards End": "Only connect"."

(6, 4).clue: The world of high fashion & high society may be called the "beau" this, literally French for "fine world"

(1, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a constellation on the monitor.)  The constellation Andromeda lies chained to a rock; this hero is next to her in the heavens waiting to rescue her

(3, 5).clue: The topic of the paper he gave to the Manchester Literary & Philosophical Society in 1794 was color blindness

(4, 5).clue: On January 1 in Ancient Rome, citizens gave each other small coins with an image of this god on them

(5, 5).clue: For "The Razor's Edge", he chose the apt "The sharp edge of a razor is difficult to pass over"

(6, 5).clue: Antiquers know this French term for "Chinese-style" furniture such as 18th c. Chinese Chippendale

(0, 0).clue: This nickname given a bomber at a 1935 test flight reflected the early belief that it wouldn't need fighter protection
